articles.headline: British Tabloid’s Web Site Makes Foray Into America
articles.snippet: Mail Online, The Daily Mail’s site, has expanded on the news and business sides with offices in New York, and coverage of celebrities in Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: Mail Online, The Daily Mail’s site, has expanded on the news and business sides with offices in New York, and coverage of celebrities in Los Angeles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent days, one of the most comprehensive destinations for gossip about the Cleveland kidnapping victims was not an American news outlet. It was Mail Online, the Web site of The Daily Mail, a British tabloid that has taken a distinctly gossipy approach to all news.

articles.headline: Challenge to Dogma on Owning a Home
articles.snippet: The benefits of homeownership are cited repeatedly in justifying the tax breaks given to home buyers. But a study has tied homeownership with rising levels of unemployment.
articles.abstract: The benefits of homeownership are cited repeatedly in justifying the tax breaks given to home buyers. But a study has tied homeownership with rising levels of unemployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Homeownership is a good thing, for the individual and for society. Or so American governments, whether Republican or Democrat, have long believed. The benefits have been cited repeatedly in justifying the existence and expansion of the tax breaks given to home buyers.

articles.headline: Pro-Inflation Policies Show Signs of Helping the Japanese Economy
articles.snippet: The Bank of Japan’s efforts to reinvigorate the nation’s economy are showing results, at least in the sinking value of the yen.
articles.abstract: The Bank of Japan’s efforts to reinvigorate the nation’s economy are showing results, at least in the sinking value of the yen.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For almost two decades Japan’s economic fortunes have deteriorated, and little seemed to be done about it.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: California Sues JPMorgan Chase Over Credit Card Cases
articles.snippet: California’s top law enforcement official accused JPMorgan Chase on Thursday of flooding the state’s courts with questionable lawsuits to collect a glut of overdue credit card debt.
articles.abstract: California’s top law enforcement official accused JPMorgan Chase on Thursday of flooding the state’s courts with questionable lawsuits to collect a glut of overdue credit card debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: California’s top law enforcement official accused JPMorgan Chase on Thursday of flooding the state’s courts with questionable lawsuits to collect overdue credit card debt.

articles.headline: Bombings Make a Bitter Bookend for F.B.I.’s Director
articles.snippet: As hearings into the Boston bombings begin, the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III is facing new scrutiny, months from his plans to step down.
articles.abstract: As hearings into the Boston bombings begin, the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III is facing new scrutiny, months from his plans to step down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III was awakened at home close to 1:30 a.m. on April 19 as one suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing was in cardiac arrest and the other was on the run.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: After Plant Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
articles.snippet: Last month’s devastating blast in West, Tex., did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance.
articles.abstract: Last month’s devastating blast in West, Tex., did little to shake local skepticism of government regulations, and recent efforts to push for more oversight have faced strong resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST, Tex. — Five days after an explosion at a fertilizer plant leveled a wide swath of this town, Gov. Rick Perry tried to woo Illinois business officials by trumpeting his state’s low taxes and limited regulations. Asked about the disaster, Mr. Perry responded that more government intervention and increased spending on safety inspections would not have prevented what has become one of the nation’s worst industrial accidents in decades.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina, Manny Fernandez and John Schwartz

articles.headline: In Its Efforts to Integrate Roma, Slovakia Recalls U.S. Struggles
articles.snippet: Eastern Slovakia’s elementary schools are a microcosm of one of Europe’s biggest challenges: how to bring its most disadvantaged minority into the mainstream.
articles.abstract: Eastern Slovakia’s elementary schools are a microcosm of one of Europe’s biggest challenges: how to bring its most disadvantaged minority into the mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARISSKE MICHALANY, Slovakia — Gazing out his window during morning recess on his first day at work, the principal of an elementary school here, Jaroslav Valastiak, was caught up short: all the children playing in the asphalt-covered yard were white, a strikingly monochromatic scene at a school where a majority of pupils are dark-skinned Roma.

articles.headline: Citrus Disease With No Cure Is Ravaging Florida Groves
articles.snippet: Efforts to find a way to stop the spread of citrus greening have failed, and the damage is growing increasingly extensive, especially to oranges.
articles.abstract: Efforts to find a way to stop the spread of citrus greening have failed, and the damage is growing increasingly extensive, especially to oranges.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVON PARK, Fla. — Florida’s citrus industry is grappling with the most serious threat in its history: a bacterial disease with no cure that has infected all 32 of the state’s citrus-growing counties.

articles.headline: 17 Days in Darkness, a Cry of ‘Save Me,’ and Joy
articles.snippet: A woman named Reshma was found gasping but alive in the wreckage of a garment building, and the reaction in Bangladesh was euphoric.
articles.abstract: A woman named Reshma was found gasping but alive in the wreckage of a garment building, and the reaction in Bangladesh was euphoric.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Day after day, the grim drudgery of digging for bodies had progressed at Rana Plaza. Talk of rescuing survivors had faded. This was the recovery phase, and what was being recovered were corpses, the numbers spinning remorselessly forward: 700 dead became 800, then 900, with no end in sight.
articles.byline: By Julfikar Ali Manik and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Student Debt Slows Growth as Young Spend Less
articles.snippet: The anemic economy has left millions struggling to get ahead. Student debt is making it even harder for many of them, as they delay purchases of things like homes and cars.
articles.abstract: The anemic economy has left millions struggling to get ahead. Student debt is making it even harder for many of them, as they delay purchases of things like homes and cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The anemic economy has left millions of younger working Americans struggling to get ahead. The added millstone of student loan debt, which recently exceeded $1 trillion in total, is making it even harder for many of them, delaying purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists said.
